newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks close higher on China shipping hope.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks close higher on China shipping hope.

text.p: Strong buying in shipping stocks pushed Taiwan share prices to a sharply higher close on Wednesday, one day after China issued rules governing direct shipping links with the island.
The weighted index shot up 120.34 points or 1.99 percent to finish at 6,177.78. Turnover was T$42.4 billion.
Recent official comments that the island's economic policy toward China would not change also boosted buying in firms with mainland investments, brokers said.

"Sentiment was very bullish today but players should bear in mind that the government won't allow investments in mainland China without restrictions and direct shipping links will still take time," said Albert Lin of Golden Securities.

China said on Tuesday regulations on direct shipping links were effective immediately. But Taipei, saying Beijing's rules were "belated" and "mingled with sensitive political issues," still bans direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait.

Yang Ming Marine soared T$1.8 to T$37.8 after the company signed a joint slot exchange agreement with China's China Ocean Shipping Global Co. The pact allows Yang Ming to cover trade between North Europe and Japan, China and Asia.

President Enterprises, Taiwan's biggest China investor, rose T$1.3 to 40.1. Formosa Plastics Group member Nan Ya, which said it would halt plans for a US$3 billion China power plant amid recent political uncertainties, gained T$1.9 to T$51.5.
"Recent good news on Taiwan-China economic ties should support the market in the near term," said Mike Tsai of Grand Cathay Securities.
Despite the overall optimism, brokers noted the possibility of profit-taking from gains since Tuesday.
They said market focus would remain on China-concept shares as well as shipping issues in the near term.
Initial resistance was seen above 6,200 points while support was at 6,100.
